required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Nocturnal Symptoms and Quality of Life in Patients With Parkinson's Disease in Shanghai
clinical_study.official_title: Nocturnal Symptoms and Quality of Life in Patients With Parkinson's Disease in Shanghai

lead_sponsor.agency: Xinhua Hospital, Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: Xinhua Hospital, Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: This is a cross-sectional, retrospective clinical observation study focusing on the incidence and influencing factors of nocturnal symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease.

detailed_description.textblock: This study was a cross-sectional, retrospective clinical observation study investigating the incidence and influencing factors of nocturnal symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease through the Parkinson's disease sleep-related scale. At the same time, the effects of nocturnal symptoms on the quality of life of patients with Parkinson's disease were studied. About 1,500 Parkinson's patients will be recruited into the study who come from Shanghai, China.

primary_outcome.measure: nocturnal symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease
primary_outcome.description: the incidence and influencing factors of nocturnal symptoms in patients with Parkinson's disease

arm_group.description: Parkinson's disease patients with or without nocturnal symptoms

intervention.description: Parkinson's disease patients with or without nocturnal symptoms

study_pop.textblock: Parkinson's disease patients diagnosed according to the diagnostic criteria of MDS

overall_official.affiliation: Xinhua Hospital, Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

facility.name: Xinhua Hospital Affiliated to Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

reference.citation: Grandas F, Iranzo A. Nocturnal problems occurring in Parkinson's disease. Neurology. 2004 Oct 26;63(8 Suppl 3):S8-11. Review.
